subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4.4 released
msgSnippet: ... Out of the box (i.e. using the assertion as above) you get the following error message: java.lang.AssertionError: Expression: (languages[tom] == [Java,
messageBody:
> Paul,
>
> That's great. I've seen some slick stuff done with Theories in
> Groovy. What is the error message if a line like this fails?
>
> assert languages['tom'] == ["Java", "Groovy"]
>
> Do you get an informative message? Thanks,
>

Out of the box (i.e. using the assertion as above) you get the following
error message:

java.lang.AssertionError: Expression: (languages[tom] == [Java,
Groovy]). Values: languages = {tom=[JavaScript, Groovy],
dick=[C#, Ruby]}

This is informative but probably not as pretty as possible. Using
assertThat from the same example (i.e. assertThat languages['tom'],
is(["Java", "Groovy"])) yields:

java.lang.AssertionError:
Expected: is <[Java, Groovy]>
got: <[JavaScript, Groovy]>

So, a friendlier error message bug arguably a less friendly expression
of the test.

You can always use JUnit's assertEquals by statically importing
assertEquals (i.e. test becomes assertEquals languages['tom'], ["Java",
"Groovy"]), you get:

java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<[JavaScript, Groovy]> but
was:<[Java, Groovy]>

And of course you can roll your own error message at anytime with the
normal assert, i.e. this test:

assert languages['tom'] == ["Java", "Groovy"], \
"\n Expected: ${["Java", "Groovy"]}\nbut found:
${languages['tom']}"

produces this result:

java.lang.AssertionError:
Expected: ["Java", "Groovy"]
but found: ["JavaScript", "Groovy"].

Though you would probably refactor out 'actual' and 'expected' as
variables in this case, i.e. perhaps something like this:

def actual = languages['tom']
def expected = ["Java", "Groovy"]
assert actual == expected, """
Expected: $expected
but found: $actual"""


Cheers, Paul.

> David Saff
>
> On 7/21/07, Paul King <paulk@...
> <mailto:paulk%40asert.com.au>> wrote:
> > David Saff wrote:
> > > We're very pleased to announce the release of JUnit 4.4.
> >
> > Well done JUnit team!
> >
> > I updated the Using Groovy with JUnit 4 page to show off some
> > of the new features:
> >
> > http://groovy.codehaus.org/Using+JUnit+4+with+Groovy
> <http://groovy.codehaus.org/Using+JUnit+4+with+Groovy>
> >
> > Cheers, Paul.
> >
>
